quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: State and U.s.
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, nicknames, sonora. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In which US state was Fathers Day first celebrated?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: West Virginia

questions.question: Sonora Smart Dodd began a movement to establish Fathers Day as an officially recognized holiday. In which state did she live?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Washington

questions.question: Which of these nicknames has been given to the U.S. state of Nevada?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Silver State

questions.question: Which U.S. state has been nicknamed The Tar Heel State?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: North Carolina

questions.question: Which of these U.S. states is nicknamed The Outer Space State?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Mexico

questions.question: The U.S. state of California is known by this fruity nickname.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Grape State

questions.question: Which of these Presidents was very vocal in advocating  Fathers Day as a National Holiday?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Coolidge

questions.question: Which U.S. state has been called The Land of the Midnight Sun?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alaska

questions.question: This sweet nickname has been given to the U.S. state of Louisiana.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sugar State

questions.question: What U.S. state has been nicknamed The Baked Bean State?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Massachusetts

questions.question: This culinary nickname has been given to the U.S. state of Nebraska?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Beef State

questions.question: Which U.S. state is also known as The Beehive State?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Utah

questions.question: Who was the first President to celebrate Fathers Day in the White House?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wilson

questions.question: Which of these nicknames belongs to the U.S. state of Kansas?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wheat State

questions.question: In which of these countries is Fathers Day not celebrated on the third Sunday of June?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Dominican Republic

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Movie and Samhain
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, festival, reaction. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which one of these actors was not in the movie Fathers Day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alan King

questions.question: Which President was first to declare the third Sunday in June as Fathers Day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lyndon B. Johnson

questions.question: Halloween is typically linked to the ancient harvest festival of Samhain held on October 31–November 1. What is the origin of Samhain?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Celtic

questions.question: What is E.T. disguised as on Halloween in Steven Spielbergs classic sci-fi movie E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ghost

questions.question: This character from the Disney film The Nightmare Before Christmas is a being from Halloween Town who opens a portal to Christmas Town.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack Skellington

questions.question: This movie presented a realistic look at a familys reaction to a mothers suicide.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Father Figure

questions.question: What kind of creature is Eddie Munster from the 1960s TV sitcom The Munsters?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: werewolf

questions.question: The popular Halloween custom trick-or-treating has its roots in the late medieval practice of souling, when poor people would go door to door on Hallowmas. The practice is mentioned in this Shakespearean comedy when Speed accuses his master of puling [whimpering or whining] like a beggar at Hallowmas.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Two Gentlemen of Verona

questions.question: In the 1989 movie Dad Ted Danson becomes his fathers caretaker as a result of which they become closer. Who played his father?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack Lemmon

questions.question: In Agatha Christies detective novel Halloween Party, Hercule Poirot must unmask the real evil of Halloween night by investigating the murder of a girl named Joyce Reynolds. How was she murdered?

options.text: She was stabbed by a neighbour while trick-or-treating.
She was drowned in an apple-bobbing tub.
She was stabbed by a man disguised as a skeleton.
She was hit with a jack-o-lantern.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: She was drowned in an apple-bobbing tub.

questions.question: Halloween traditions were brought to North America by Irish immigrants between 1845 and 1852. What term is used to refer to this period?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the Great Famine

questions.question: The Witches Spell, which came to be regarded as a Halloween poem, is spoken in what Shakespearean play?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Macbeth

questions.question: Devils Night is chiefly associated with the serious vandalism and arson seen in this US city on October 30.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Detroit, Michigan

questions.question: The Great Pumpkin is an unseen character in this comic strip created by Charles M. Schulz.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peanuts

questions.question: What root vegetable was carved and placed in windows to ward off evil spirits in traditional Celtic Halloween festivals?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: turnip

quizzes.title: Science Quiz: South Carolina and India
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, college, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: As of 1830, South Carolina had the largest population of any of the states of this class of people.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jews

questions.question: What was the first public university in South Carolina to admit a black student in the 20th century and in what year did this happen?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Clemson University, 1962

questions.question: Cochin is the capital of the Indian state Kerala.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: In folklore and popular culture there is a strong connection between pumpkins and the supernatural. Which of these statements concerning the appearance of pumpkins in fiction is true?

options.text: A character from the Oz book series by L. Frank Baum has a jack olantern for a head.
Pumpkin Juice is a drink favored among the students at the fictional Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
The Headless Horseman hurls a pumpkin in The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: This beautiful small city in South Carolina was named for the president of the South Carolina Canal and Railroad Company, who built the first railroad that went through it. It was famous for years for its winter colony and its horse industry, and later as a center of nuclear technology. Polo matches are played on Sunday afternoons there.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aiken

questions.question: This American Revolutionary battle is considered to be the turning point in the southern campaigns since it forced General Cornwallis to split his troops, making his plan for a major push north impossible.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kings Mountain

questions.question: Which motto graces the license plates of South Carolina automobiles?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Smiling Faces, Beautiful Places

questions.question: Mahatma Gandhi was the first president of India.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: India is the 17th-largest country in the world in terms of area.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: South Carolina declared its independence from Great Britain at the same time as the rest of the colonies, on July 4th, 1776.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This university was established as South Carolina College in 1801. Its first class had 9 students. Its most notable architectural feature is called the horseshoe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The University of South Carolina

questions.question: Where is the only active volcano in India?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Barren Island

questions.question: Two agricultural crops, both cultivated by slave labor, were the primary reason that South Carolina was one of the wealthiest of the colonies before the American Revolution. What were the two crops?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: rice and indigo

questions.question: Which of the following famous people is NOT a native of South Carolina?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Dickey

questions.question: From the name of which river is the name India derived?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sindhu river

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: England and Haifa
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, gibside, tyne. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What British prime minister lived in Hughenden Manor, Buckinghamshire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benjamin Disraeli

questions.question: On which mountain is the city of Haifa located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mount Carmel

questions.question: What is the national fruit of India?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: mango

questions.question: What ghost allegedly appeared in Gibside Hall, Tyne and Wear, England?

options.text: The ghost of a servant- girl
The ghost of a white lady

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The ghost of a countess

questions.question: In which part of Israel is the beautiful city of Haifa situated?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: North

questions.question: Visitors of Powis Castle in Powys, Wales have reported seeing which of the following?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a lady in black

questions.question: Which of the following is believed to haunt the Queen’s bedroom in Belton House in Lincolnshire, England?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Gentleman in Black

questions.question: Lanhydrock in Cornwall is thought to be home to several ghosts, including a man believed to have been hanged outside the gatehouse by Civil War Royalists.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: How was Lady Elinor Cavendish murdered in Newton House, Dinefwr, Carmarthenshire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: She was strangled.

questions.question: When is the ghost of Anne Boleyn believed to appear in Hever Castle in Kent, England?

options.text: on the anniversary of her execution

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: on the anniversary of her execution

questions.question: Which statement is true about Haifa?

options.text: Haifa is located on the Gulf of Aden.
Haifa has the only train system completely inside of any Israeli city.
Haifa is the center of Israels avocado industry.
Haifa is the oldest city in Israel.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Haifa has the only train system completely inside of any Israeli city.

questions.question: Who is believed to haunt Dunster Castle in England?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The man in green

questions.question: Lyme Park in Cheshire, England is believed to be haunted by which of the following?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Phantom funeral cortege

questions.question: What is the capital of India?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Delhi

questions.question: Quarry Bank Mil in Cheshire, England is thought to be haunted by a group of former workers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Haifa and Aircraft
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, schools, headquarters. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What do the following cities have in common with Haifa: Portsmouth in UK, Marseille in France, Antwerp in Belgium?

options.text: They are approximately the same size as Haifa.
They are some of the sister cites of Haifa.
They have approximately the same population as Haifa.
The are all on the same latitude as Haifa.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They are some of the sister cites of Haifa.

questions.question: When he was Democratic Chairman, this future Postmaster General was instrumental in brokering the deal that put Truman on the ticket with FDR. He also was owner of the St. Louis Cardinals for a short time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert E. Hannegan

questions.question: During the Civil War the Confederacy had a Postmaster General, called Confederate-Post Office Department Postmaster General.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In which type of aircraft is the tailplane located ahead of the main lifting surfaces?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: canard

questions.question: Which best describes the climate of Haifa?

options.text: Warm, wet winters and very hot, dry summers
Cool, wet winters and hot, humid summers
Cool wet winters and hot, very dry summers
Warm winters and very hot summers

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cool, wet winters and hot, humid summers

questions.question: What is the name of the aircrafts main body section that holds crew, passengers or cargo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: fuselage

questions.question: What are the names of the two schools of higher education in Haifa?

options.text: Haifa University and Ben Gurion Universitry.
Haifa University and Bar Ilan University.
Bar Ilan University and the Weitzmann Institute.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Haifa University and the Technion.

questions.question: In which of these sports are Haifas teams most successful?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Soccer

questions.question: Ailerons are hinged control surfaces on the edge of the airplane wing, used to control the aircraft in which rotation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: roll

questions.question: In what year was the position of Postmaster General removed from the cabinet and placed in the United States Postal Department itself?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1971

questions.question: Haifa contains one of Israels three oil refineries.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What religion’s headquarters is located in the city of Haifa?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: BaHai

questions.question: What was the claim to fame of Winton M. Blount from Alabama?

options.text: She was the first woman Postmaster General.
He was the first Black Postmaster General.
He was the last Postmaster General to be seated as a cabinet member.
He held the position of Postmaster General for 18 years.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was the last Postmaster General to be seated as a cabinet member.

questions.question: This former publisher of the Los Angeles Times, CEO of Times-Mirror Company and CEO of American Airlines, served as U.S. Postmaster General under Ronald Reagan.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert V. Casey

questions.question: Haifa has its own airport – the Haifa Airport.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Helicopters and Aircraft
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, helicopters, ship. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Nacelle, a French word meaning small boat, refers to what in aviation?

options.text: a covered housing for the aircraft engines
a major part of the hydraulic system of the aircraft
the middle part of the aircraft

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a covered housing for the aircraft engines

questions.question: In 1918, these two engineers were first to introduce the co-axial design of helicopters, where rotors are at the top of the aircraft.

options.text: Juan de la Cierva and Arthur Young
Theodore von Karman and Asboth Oszkar

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore von Karman and Asboth Oszkar

questions.question: The modern English word Easter is derived from which of the following?

options.text: The name of a mythological beast
The name of a pagan goddess

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The name of a pagan goddess

questions.question: Which of the following aircraft controls is usually located in a helicopters cockpit?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: collective

questions.question: As part of Easter celebrations, Easter Fires are traditionally lit in what location?

options.text: Indoors, in front of a crucifix
On the Easter table, in the form of candles

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Out in the open

questions.question: Which term refers to the angle between the wing of a plane and the local horizon?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: dihedral angle

questions.question: In Norway, there is a tradition of reading this type of books and watching this type of films around Easter.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Detective movies and books

questions.question: The merchant ship Mary Celeste was discovered unmanned in the Atlantic Ocean in 1972.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a jet engine?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: sliding valve

questions.question: What merchant schooner was found near of the Coast of North Carolina in 1921 without any crew?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Caroll A. Deering

questions.question: The Christian holiday Easter is linked to which big Jewish holiday?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Passover

questions.question: What is the acronym for the small generator, used to start the main engines of an aircraft?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: APU

questions.question: Which of these is commemorated annually on Maundy Thursday?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Last Supper

questions.question: Which of the following navigation instruments is located in the cockpit of an airplane?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: omnibearing selector

questions.question: What British Royal Navy ship commanded by Fairfax Moresby disappeared in Australia in 1857?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sappho
